line_1: To cure the direful train of human ills.
line_2: At his command gush out thy crystal rills,

line_1: Who feel'st no sense of future ills, —
line_2: And thou, sweet Bird, whom rapture fills,

line_1: The lab'ring Spirit with prolific Ills
line_2: How some fierce Lust, or boist'rous Passion, fills

line_1: But we court Love with its attending Ills;
line_2: A deadly Draught the bitter Potion fills.

line_1: 'Tis true the man of verse, tho' born to ills,
line_2: Too oft deserves the very fate he feels.

line_1: Have patent powers to vanquish human ills:
line_2: And chief th' illustrious race, whose drops and pills

line_1: No! No! I will conceal my weighty Ills,
line_2: That shall to Heav'n as silent rise as Dew from thence Distills.

line_1: Hunted by all kinds of Ills,
line_2: Like a Partridge on the Hills;

line_1: And a loud laugh proclaim'd his ills.
line_2: His hand expos'd a box of pills;

line_1: Racking their brains with visionary ills.
line_2: What numbers, sloth with gloomy humours fills!

line_1: Think London journies are the worst of ills,
line_2: And set their hands to articles for bills:

line_1: A potent quack, long versed in human ills,
line_2: Who first insults the victim whom he kills;

line_1: And bids to shun, like Death, imagin'd Ills;
line_2: Who know no Medium to their wayward Wills.

line_1: But ah! not rashly trust the tempting Ills;
line_2: Too well you know, that Beauty often kills:

line_1: Poetic minds to Life, with all her ills.
Poetic minds to Life, with all her ills.
line_2: And glassy lakes, and mazy, murmuring rills,
In ev'ry Act and Turn of Life he feels

line_1: (If there can be addition to those ills)
line_2: Yet added grief my apprehension fills
